Fields.DialogueText: What are you looking at, U-29?
I've been looking at recent Nixen activity patterns, trying to make sense of some of what I perceived in my "possessed" state - and I've discovered something strange.
And what is that?
They are searching for something.
How can you tell?
Do you see these patrol patterns? They're doing regular sweeps of a 1,000 square kilometers area in the mid-Atlantik. They're trying to find something.
You have that smirk again. What's on your mind?
Well, I think I've found it.

Fields.MenuText: What is it?
Really? All of those Morganas were looking for it, and you found it?
Don't let this go to your head.

Fields.DialogueText: To be honest, I'm not totally sure, Kapitän.
What can I say? They're not me. Plus, they don't have access to our Karte.
I don't know what you mean, Kapitän.
So how did you find whatever this thing is?
I analyzed their search pattern, and identified which parts of the area they hadn't thoroughly searched yet, and then cross-referenced this with all of our naval charts of the Region.
And?
There's only one thing in all that stretch of ocean: Seagull Isle. Tiny, remote - it's not even on all of our charts.
I have no idea what the Nixen want with it, but I'm sure that's what they are looking for.
Well, I guess we should go check it out, then.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Well, we're here... Seagull Isle.
It seemed they named it pretty accurately.
It looks like the only thing of consequence is that cove. Let's hang on.
Is that a Kanu?
Ja. And the man paddling it along doesn't look well at all.
Let's get him aboard - he needs to get to the doctor!
So... is this what you were expecting?
I didn't know what to expect, Kapitän. There wasn't enough Information.
I assume that no, you were not expecting this.
Ah! We meet at last!
What?
I've been waiting for someone for a long time. A long, long time.
I'm sorry, are you living on this island? What do you eat here?
Seagulls, mostly. But that doesn't matter! You have to take this... now!. Hurry!
What is this? A book?
Kapitän, look!
Ah. Finally.
*raspy breath*
*silence*
No pulse.
*ALARM*

Fields.MenuText: It looks like the Morganas finally found this island.
Were we being followed?
It looks like we got here just in time.

Fields.DialogueText: This is too soon, based on their search pattern. Either they were drawn to us, or this is a trap.
I think so, Kapitän.
If I believed in luck, I'd agree, Kapitän. As it is, I think we were simply followed.
@BATTLE
If it's a trap, it's not a good one. They're not out in overwhelming force.
Agreed - though let's not be too complacent.
Kapitän, I've spent some time looking at that book the deceased gentleman left us.
What have you found out?
I'm not sure, really. It's full of a lot of nonsense and ramblings, and I don't think it's even complete.
On top of that, it appears to be written in a kind of mixed language that I don't entirely understand.

Fields.MenuText: Is it a journal?
Does it have his recipe for cooked seagull?
Any idea on why he wanted us to have it so urgently?

Fields.DialogueText: Nein. Not exactly.
It might, Kapitän, but I haven't seen anything that suggest the patterns of a traditional Rezept.
Why does anyone want to share a book? He didn't want its contents to die with him.
From what I gather, it tells the story of the "water of the weeping star," an ancient artifact of unclear - but supposedly great - power.
So, you're saying a dying castaway stranded on an island in the middle of nowhere is going to win the war for us. I'm sold.
That's not what I'm saying.
I know. I'm not even opposed to following up.
But half the time, the Morganas don't seem organized enough to sail in a straight line. I don't see how they could track down some poor soul on a lonely rock.
You think it's just coincidence that they were out here?
Don't you?
It's possible. But this book - even if it is just the Produkt of a delusional mind - is coherent and took some exceptional linguistic skills to create.
As I say, if you have a lead, I'm prepared to follow up on it. I don't want to miss anything that could be helpful just because it's improbable.
I think you're right.
Again, the Text itself is very interesting, and this Star Tear could at least have some archäologische significance.
*ALARM*
I thought we lost them. To your stations!
@BATTLE
And the Schrift - you see these letters here? I'd swear they're Phrygisch, though the vocabulary in the section is almost entirely Althellenisch. Very odd.
Any reports of eccentric linguists going missing in these parts?
No. And no identification on the body, or at his... campsite. Obviously, I couldn't go myself, but the search team seems to have been admirably thorough.
Right. So our primary clue here is the book itself.
Uh-huh.
You're unconvinced.
No. I would be unconvinced if you were talking about the Holy Grail or the mirror used to lure Amaterasu out of her cave - something with the weight of legend behind it.
This isn't that. This sounds more like the plot to a pulp adventure. The water of the....
Let's just call it a Sternenträne - "star tear," for the sake of convenience.
Fine. I've never heard of it before. I have absolutely no reason to believe it isn't fictional. How about you?
Well, for one thing, I believe this book gives its location - if it can be deciphered.
Twenty-nine....
It could be linked to whatever Venom used to... attack me. We know *that* power exists, and we know we need to master it.
Kapitän...
@BATTLE
How's the deciphering of that book coming along, U-29?
Gradually, Kapitän - but I think I have made an important discovery.
Tell me.
I don't think that hermit wrote this book. I think he - or someone else - copied it down, possibly from memory. And I think it is only a part of a larger text.
Is it not just that he ran out of ink on the island?
Nein.
Its Information is fragmentarisch, but a few annotations in the margins lead me to believe that there's a companion piece that might complete our understanding.
If we can find this, we can find the Star Tear.
What if we can't find this companion piece?
I'm fairly sure we'll still be able to find it. It might just take a while.

Fields.MenuText: So how is this a breakthrough? It sounds like we're just trading time spent translating for time spent searching.
This is fascinating. Tell me more.
Well, anyway, I need to get going.

Fields.DialogueText: Let me finish, Kapitän!
With pleasure.
Wait! I haven't gotten to the good part, yet.
I know where this other Text is. A few clues in the book pointed to it. It is on an island off the coast of Florida. It is a part of the Florida Keys.
Well, I suppose we should get going, then.
Don't worry, Kapitän. I believe it's one of the uninhabited islands.
Oh, boy.
I see them!
And we've been asked to provide support for a joint operation in the Karibik anyway.
Right.
We're almost as close as we can get without running aground, U-29. Any idea where we should look?
Let's go a little bit West. I need to compare the Terrain to the Illustration in this book.
I have to say, this doesn't seem like the best place to store a book. It's so humid.
Ja. We can expect the Text to be in a state of decomposition. I'm hoping it will be better underground, though. Here we go. Do you see that mound over there?
Yes.
There should be some very old Strukturen beneath it.

Fields.MenuText: How old are the ruins?
Really?
Hmm, is this like a burial mound?

Fields.DialogueText: Well how old do you think the Ruinen are? They could be thousands of years old.
Now, are you doubting me?
It is something similar to a burial mound, Kapitän.
Prepare the boat, Leutnant. Twenty-nine, do you have any notes for us?
Nein. Just be careful.
Oh, okay... well, it doesn't look like there's any danger around here.
I mean... be careful with the Text. It is very old.
*ALARM*
It seems as though our expedition will have to wait a bit.
@BATTLE
Let me just be clear. You're saying that this book, written in some Greek-Phrygian hybrid, has revealed the location of another book in some sort of Bronze Age cairn off the Florida coast.
Say rather that the book has helped me to clarify some of the impressions I received from Venom, and those have led to our current search.
Then why haven't the Morganas been here first? If Venom knows-
She may know, but she doesn't understand what she knows, Kapitän. Or, at least, that is my working Hypothese. We know the enemy is broken in fundamental ways.
But you think they were around thousands of years ago? Is this first-hand knowledge, or what?
Ich weiß es nicht. We need more Informationen before we can make even remotely educated guesses.
And you're sure that Venom isn't playing you?
Again, you mean.
That's right.
I can only say that I'm proceeding with my eyes open, Kapitän. And I'm very glad that you're doing the same.
... Right.
Ummm...
@BATTLE
Whew!
Those Nixen put up a hard fight.
We got the better of them, though. Just like always. Now, let's check out that mound.
Oh nein!
What's wrong?
It's already open. I think, Kapitän, I think that was a distraction.
... This changes some of my assumptions.
Be that as it may - we can still send a team to check, but it looks like the Nixen have the other text.

Fields.MenuText: Right. How worried should we be?
So what do we do now?
This could be a problem.

Fields.DialogueText: Worry is konterproduktiv. I will say that I think the odds of the Star Tear actually existing and having useful supernatural properties are low - but I'd rather not let the Nixen prove me wrong.
We need to keep going. They don't have any more Informationen than we do - it is just a different piece of the Puzzle.
Maybe, Kapitän.
Just as our half of the Text is enough to find the Star Tear with time, I believe the text the Nixen have recovered could supply them with its location, as well.
So, is it a race?
It looks like it, Kapitän.
... This is really not the war I was expecting on August 31, 1939.
Kapitän! Kapitän!
What is it?
I've made a breakthrough on the Text, Kapitän. It is more than just a book - it is a Karte, of sorts. It is a guide on a scavenger hunt that ends with the Star Tear.
Is that the breakthrough?
Ja, partially. And I know where we need to go.

Fields.MenuText: You're really enjoying this, aren't you?
You do like to be dramatic with this.
Well?

Fields.DialogueText: Ja, I am. Is it obvious?
What?!
You don't sound very impressed, Kapitän. I'm hurt.
So, where is it?
There are Ruinen near the Mexikanischen coast - here, in the shadow of the Tuxtla Mountains. They should be Olmec, but I don't think they are. Within, we should find our next clue.
We have Morganas inbound!
I think our friends would like to find those ruins, too.
@BATTLE
Are we close to the Ruinen?
@BATTLE
We're on our way to the ruins!
Exzellent. I hope they're close to the shore. I'd like to see what's there with my own eyes, if possible.
Can we talk about this Star Tear? What is it actually supposed to do? You were saying you thought it might be connected to... whatever went into making your evil mask?
It's most likely nothing at all. If there *is* something there, it's... well, I hesitate to say.
If the Tear is real. And if it's where it's supposed to be.
Ja und ja.
I will admit that I'm intrigued by all this. A tattered book written in a strange language, given to us by a dying hermit on a remote island? It's very pulp.
And you're open to the possibility that it's a weapon of some kind.
And the visions, or impressions from Venom, or whatever it was that tipped you off to this? They're irrelevant?
Not just you - but yes. Remember when you were possessed in your sleep by a necklace?
How could I not? But just because you've experienced the supernatural, does not mean it should become the stick by which you measure your whole life.
I've said this before, and I'll say it again - jumping to such conclusions is not scientific or Germanic, and I won't have it.
Tell that to the Ahnenerbe.
Ja. Well there are many things in this world that are not scientific or Germanic.
Regardless, everything about the Star Tear remains uncertain. I can only trust it will be clarified in time.

Fields.MenuText: You're a complicated Belle, U-29.
I guess I can respect that, but I'm not going to be complacent. I've seen too many strange things.
But aren't you always reading those pulp mystery novels?

Fields.DialogueText: Hm. Aren't we all?
I'm not arguing for complacency. I'm arguing for a thorough investigation.
Those novels are fictional stories, Kapitän, not real life. And I certainly don't spend all of  my time reading novels!
Uh, no.
The Maske wasn't evil. The creature behind it may have been, but the thing itself is just a tool.
As for the Star Tear, most of what I've been able to piece together is more about how important it is to the forces that are battling for it.
It's clearly apokalyptisch in tone, though I can't tell if it's prophecy or history. The "Children of Darkness" or "People of the Countries of the Sea" began attacking established trade routes...
Sounds familiar.
Ja. But we shouldn't make assumptions.

Regardless, the stars themselves were so appalled by the violence that they began to cry, and the tears were supposed to cleanse the world - which could mean either assistance or a catastrophic flood.
And...?
That's a very good question. Both sides tried to gain control of the heavenly water, but I don't know how it worked out.
But this object - or water, or whatever - we're hunting is that?
But this journey we're on could have significant archäologische and cultural ramifications, if nothing else.
It's possible it was a religious implement of some sort that was used in warfare.
You're being evasive.
Nothing I've read suggests that it allows for mind control, or Astralprojektion, or anything else that might apply to what I experienced before.
Therefore, it has no unusual or supernatural properties that I have personally documented. That, in turn, means that we should proceed with no assumptions about same.
They're unverifiable. And I thought you were skeptical of all this.
If Morganas are interested, I can't afford too much skepticism - purely as a matter of security.
You're worried that I'm vulnerable.
We've arrived at the Koordinaten U-29 gave us, Kapitän.
Thank you, Leutnant.
Scheisse. It *is* on land.
We'll surely take plenty of pictures!
I'll need rubbings of any carvings as well.
Okay, we're heading out. We'll stay in touch by radio.
*SOME TIME LATER*
<U-29, by radio> What do you see, Kapitän?
It's pretty dark and wet, but we're collecting all the information we can find. For the record, there are giant stone heads everywhere, and they don't look like they approve of us.
More to the point, they're... stylistically not what I expected. Not consistent with the photographs I've seen of more familiar sites in the region.
Beyond just being creepier, I mean.
<U-29, by radio> Interessant.

Fields.MenuText: Is that relevant, U-29?
It might be interesting, but it's still creepy.
Isn't it?

Fields.DialogueText: <U-29, by radio> Not immediately, Kapitän. I just think it's interesting.
<U-29, by radio> I didn't take you for a coward, Kapitän.
<U-29, by radio> I wish I was there now.
<U-29, by radio> Scheisse!
<U-29, by radio> We have Nixen closing in, Kapitän. We need to collect you now!
@BATTLE
@BATTLE
Second expedition underway. And we're pushing further into the ruins.
<U-29, over the radio> Tell me if you see anything interesting.
How interesting?
<U-29, over the radio> I don't know, just interesting.
You think everything is interesting.
<U-29, over the radio> You say that like it's a bad thing.
No, U-29. But if I described a snake for you, could you tell me if it's poisonous?
<U-29, over the radio> ... Maybe.
Oh, never mind. Schulz shot it.
Hello!
<U-29, over the radio> What is it?

Fields.MenuText: I think I found what we're looking for.
I'm sorry to say we might not need you to crack this one after all.
Something interesting.

Fields.DialogueText: <U-29, over the radio> Oh?
<U-29, over the radio> Hmm. Is that so?
<U-29, over the radio> Go on.
I think I might know where we need to go. There's a map here, a world map. It's pretty stylized, but I can still make it out.
<U-29, over the radio> Was? That's impossible!
Evidently not. And there's a spot marked on the map.
We're going to Antarctica.
Do you understand what this means?
All too well.
An ancient Olmec world map! This will shake Archaeologie to its core. Ha! I'd like to see what those hacks at the Ahnenerbe would do with this.
Assuming it's Olmec, despite the stylistic differences. Assuming it's not more recent.
Do you think it's more recent?
I think it's weird.
It also means we'll have to risk a trip to Antarctica.
This all makes sense, in a way. That Text is so strange! My field isn't really linguistics, but I can pick out Akkadisch - and there are some characters that I'd swear are an offshoot of Linear B...
Are you listening to me?
Es tut mir Leid. But there are pieces of some language I don't recognize at all, which has huge implications!

Fields.MenuText: Traveling to Antarctica isn't exactly a safe voyage!
Can we even manage a trip to Antarctica?
I need you to focus a little more on planning this voyage to Antarctica.

Fields.DialogueText: We're in the middle of a war, Kapitän. There is no such thing as a safe voyage.
Of course we can, Kapitän. I'm of the finest German construction!
Entschuldigung, Kapitän.
*ALARM*
We are going to have a lot of company until we find the Star Tear, aren't we?
@BATTLE
Do you feel like playing some chess, U-29?
Absolut, Kapitän. It will give me a break from studying the Material we gathered.
Have you found anything new?
We already have enough to chew on. The implications of this are enormous - a prehistoric, globally-aware Zivilisation that was far more advanced than anything we had considered for that Periode.
It feels really strange to be playing the skeptic with you, U-29, but you're making a pretty big leap without a whole lot of evidence.
I well, I have a Hypothese, and we're trying to collect evidence to test it. I'm allowed to be excited if it doesn't affect my Methodik.
Granted.
So, your hypothesis is what, Atlantis? Lemuria? Some civilization before civilization?
It's possible. Parts of the Text could be written in some proto-language that acts as a predecessor to all the languages we know of.
Yeah, but I saw modern alphabets. And even the Classical stuff dates the document to after some hazy early Indo-European past.
Partial translations. Attempts to record oral histories phonetisch. The grammar and the vocabulary are more important than the script.
I'm not saying the Papier itself is thousands of years old.

Fields.MenuText: It still sounds hard to believe.
You must be very excited, U-29.
Am I castling correctly?

Fields.DialogueText: I have to agree with you, Kapitän. And yet, it's where the evidence has taken me.
I won't deny it, Kapitän.
I'm still surprised that an Offizer of your talents has such a problem remembering the Rochade, Kapitän.
*ALARM*
Schachmatt.
Let's use that tactical acumen on the Morganas.
@BATTLE
Endlich!
Verdammt, it's cold.
You've mentioned that once or twice.
Well, Kapitän, it is cold.
That ice cave up ahead should be what we're looking for.
That's a Tunnel, not a cave.
It is big enough for Belles... that's all that matters.
Or Nixen.
Okay. U-29. You say this is the location, but how can you be so sure?
I've done the reading, Kapitän. Do you see anything of note around here?

Fields.MenuText: And you're sure this is the right place?
Yeah, I don't think those penguins over there will have information on an ancient prehistoric artifact.
I guess not.

Fields.DialogueText: Kapitän, Kapitän. Are you really asking me if I'm sure?
Nein, but I will want to check them out on our way back. I haven't observed Pinguine first hand before.
Exactly. So we'll check out the ice cave.
Kapitän! Up ahead, in the cave!
Morganas!
@BATTLE
Well, we cleared out all the Morganas, but this cave seems to go on forever. Keep that spotlight moving, sailor.
If anything, that only confirms that this is the right place.
I suppose you're right. What the hell?
What the hell?
Was zur Hölle?
U-29, do you have any idea what we're looking at?
Um, Ruinen?
But of what?
I have no idea, Kapitän. Structurally, it almost looks like a Schiff.
But not any ship I've ever seen before.
And those carvings. They look so...

Fields.MenuText: ... otherworldly.
... alien.
... unappealing.

Fields.DialogueText: I suppose so, Kapitän, but ancient things often do look otherworldly.
They are strange, aren't they?
That's one way of putting it, Kapitän.
Well, do you think you can still get what we need?
I think so, Kapitän. A lot of these Symbole are piktographisch. I should be able to decipher them if we can get some rubbings.
All right. I'll get some crew on that.
*ALARM*
More of them?!
@BATTLE
This damn Tunnel never ends. It never warms up, either.
Kapitän!, Kapitän! come here and look at this!
What is it, U-29?
Kapitän, look at this! There is something in the ice. Look!

Fields.MenuText: Oh!
What in the hell is that?
I can't believe it. It's a martian.

Fields.DialogueText: I know!
It's a discovery, Kapitän. A great discovery!
I highly doubt that, Kapitän.
Can we get it out?
U-29, we're leaving right now.
Was? Nein! We need to study it.
U-29, that's not... That's not human.
Obviously.
It doesn't look right. It looks dangerous. Are those fins? Tentacles? It's not even shaped like an animal.
Kapitän, I don't know what you're so afraid of. It's clearly long dead.
Did it just move?
Of course not.
No, the ice cracked. There! It moved again.
In Ordnung, we can leave.
*ALARM*
I can't believe I'm saying this, but I'm glad it's just Morganas this time.
@BATTLE
Chess rematch?
Danke. I could use the break.
How's the research coming?
I don't know. To be honest, Kapitän, I'm in over my head. And that's not something you're likely to hear from me ever again.
No doubt you're right. Check.
I see you've done some research of your own. The thing is, none of this is really my specialty. Mathe, Ozeanographie, nautical history - those fields, I'm an expert on.
But ancient history?Kryptozoologie? Strange languages? I don't know, Kapitän. I feel like I'm just muddling through all this. Schachmatt in ten turns.

Fields.MenuText: You don't seem like you're muddling through.
You're being remarkably... open right now, U-29.
Wait, are you sure about that?

Fields.DialogueText: Maybe my muddling is a part of an average person's normal way of life.
I'm just tired.
Ja. But why don't we play it out and see?
*ALARM*
Well, just as long as we have our friends keeping us company, we'll know we're on the right track.
@BATTLE
Everyone, get to your Station!
@BATTLE
I think I've got it figured out, Kapitän.
That's great to hear, U-29. Tell me about it.
Well, at first, I thought this whole thing worked like a trail each location was like a Brotkrumen leading us to the next site.
And at first, that was true: Seagull Isle led us to the Florida Keys, then to the pseudo-Olmec site, which led us to Antarctica.
But, for the final site, we have to compile Informationen from every source. That's what I was missing. That's the final piece, that allows us to put all the pieces together.
And once I figured it out, I was able to do just that. I know where the final site is. I know where to find the Star Tear.

Fields.MenuText: Well, where is it?
I knew you'd figure it out, U-29.
You're loving the suspense, aren't you?

Fields.DialogueText: I was just about to tell you, Kapitän. Calm down!
Danke, Kapitän. I appreciate the support.
If you quit interrupting, I could tell you!
The Star Tear is located on the Mediterranean Coast, somewhere near Ägypten. We're on the closing stretch.
You really are enjoying this all, aren't you, U-29?
Kapitän?
I mean to say that this is a crazy hunt for strange artifacts and historical data. For all your talk of rationality and science, you really do seem to like this.
It's true that I love a Rätsel. And I will admit, I am somewhat fascinated by the Okkultem.
Even if it's not scientific?
Selbst dann. Well, all of the supposed Okkulten is simply science that hasn't been discovered yet, as long as you don't approach it with superstition.

Fields.MenuText: I don't think I understand.
Ah, I think I understand.
Someone has to be the first person to discover something, I suppose.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm saying even the Okkultecan be scientific, if approached with skepticism.
You probably do, Kapitän. With the proper skeptical approach, even the Okkulte can be scientific.
Exactly, Kapitän. Science is a process that can be applied to anything.
And besides, I'm still not convinced this Star Tear is supernatural or okkult in any way.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Right. May I ask an awkward question?
Absolut.
How much of this is about finding a way to protect yourself from Venom?
Instead of answering directly, I wonder if I might suggest another question you might have asked.
... Okay.
You might have asked how much of this is about finding a way to get back at Venom.
Kapitän!
@BATTLE
While we wait to get to Egypt, I'd like to hear your thoughts on the Star Tear. What do you think it could be?
I've thought about that at some length, Kapitän, and I've come up with a few Theorien. Let's set aside the mythical origin and consider just the Name.
Or it could be a Juwel, cut so that it glitters in a way that is reminiscent of starlight.
Either way, my guess is that this prehistoric Zivilisation imbued it, in their minds, with great ritualistic power. What about you? What do you think the Star Tear is?

Fields.MenuText: It could be an ancient weapon that makes its bearer undefeatable.
As you said, it could be a religious artifact that is culturally important to this civilization.
Maybe it's a Martian, like that thing we saw in Antarctica.

Fields.DialogueText: I sincerely hope you're joking, Kapitän.
Selbstverständlich. I knew you'd come to agree with me.
I'm telling you, that wasn't a Marsianer.
Anyway. Whatever it is, the Morganas want it.
Ja. I'll admit I'm puzzled about that. We know so little about the Nixen. Maybe it's important to them in some way. Maybe they have simply fallen for superstition.
Its name implies some association with the heavens, so perhaps it's a fragment of a crashed Meteorit.
We're here.
What do you mean by we are here?
It's an ancient Ägyptischer Tempel, submerged under water.
Is this Egyptian?
Sort of. It's limestone - like the Pyramiden - but I think it's been treated with something to protect against erosion. Its proportions are incorrect.
So there is a possibility that it is not Ägyptisch. It could be older.
Okay. Well, let's keep going.
These Hieroglyphen are fascinating. Kapitän, look!
Oh, trust me. I'm looking.
That Hieroglyph looks just like that creature we saw in the Antarktis. Now I wish we had chiseled it out of the Eis.

Fields.MenuText: Really? Because I don't regret our decision.
Maybe you're right.
Hmm, I don't think it looks that similar.

Fields.DialogueText: You may be a brave Offizer, but you're a cowardly scientist, Kapitän.
We can still go back and get it, after we've sorted this out.
Your Strategie won't work, Kapitän. Later on, we're going back for it.
We're picking up Morganas!
I'm becoming extremely frustrated with these things.
@BATTLE
Or more recent.
With the caveat that there's no historical record of a structure of this sort falling into the sea here... sure.
@BATTLE
That was the second Morgana horde we have fought here already. What's going on?
They could have followed us here.
But that first one was already here. They beat us here.
They have the second Manuskript, after all.
It wasn't enough to beat me in the race, of course, but enough to keep up.

Fields.MenuText: Of course, they could never beat you, U-29.
But how the hell could they have decrypted the thing? You've got a huge, bizarre library - I assume they don't.
Well, now that we have that settled, let's keep moving.

Fields.DialogueText: I hope that's not Sarkasmus I just heard, Kapitän.
Maybe they got the knowledge from the same place they came from? Honestly, I don't know.
Gute Idee, Kapitän.
Wait, if they beat us here, does that mean the Star Tear is already gone?
It could be possible, but I doubt it.
That makes sense. Why else would they still be here?
There is nothing to do but press on.
This Tempelkomplex is huge. At least it's nice and open. As long as we stay on course we shouldn't hit any pillars.
Yes, ma'am.
Kapitän.
It's never good when you call my name like that!
I know what the Nixenare trying to do. I've been looking at the Hieroglyphen and inscriptions on the walls as we pass them, and...
Well, there's a reason we're encountering so many Nixen here, Kapitän. And there's a reason we keep seeing more of them as we push deeper into the Tempel.
They're trying to use the Star Tear. There's a way to activate it. A kind of Prozedur.
A ritual?
That's a loaded word. Just pay attention to your duties.
So, what is this procedure for activating the Star Tear?
Perhaps they're doing it even now. I think it's a long one.
What happens if they complete it?
I don't know, Kapitän - but it won't be good.
Unless the Star Tear is just a chunk of meteorite that somebody stuck on the end of a stick to impress the uninitiated.
Let's talk about that later, Kapitän.

Fields.MenuText: Fair enough.
That's still the most likely answer, right?
Let's just get or destroy the damn thing, and then we won't have to talk about it at all.

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you.
Ja. But, listen - I still don't think the Star Tear is likely to be supernatural, but I don't want to risk being wrong.
Guter Plan!
Let's go!
I hate it when she leaves the damn boat while we're submerged.
It's not like anyone else can just open a hatch and take a look around.
I'm not saying she shouldn't do it, Kapitän. I'm saying I hate it.
Yeah, fair enough.
I'm back! Someone give me something to draw on! And a Handtuch!
What are you seeing out there?
You can surface here, helm. It looks like we're in some underwater cave.
It appears that there's a large air cavity in this part of the Tempel.

Fields.MenuText: This can't be natural.
How long has this been here?
Whoa. This is a big area.

Fields.DialogueText: Maybe, maybe not.
Do you mean the air pocket? Who knows?
Yeah.
Look! Up ahead!
Morganas!
And they're in the middle of the ritual. We have to stop them!
Let's go!
I don't feel well.
What's happening?
I see shapes in the water! Shapes writhing! Ugh
It's like reality itself is stretching as we get closer to the ritual!
*ALARM*
Push forward, sailors!
@BATTLE
Things seem quiet.
There are no Morganas in sight, Kapitän. Search teams are still trying to find the- oh, whatever.
I think we did it. We stopped the Ritual in time!
It does look like reality stopped melting, or whatever was happening. I'll send a team in a boat out to grab the Tear.
*Time passes*
I think we have radio contact with the search party again, ma'am!
Leutnant, are you there? Can you describe the Star Tear to me?
It's like a warm lump of coral that glows.
Fascinating. Oh! What was that?
The temple is starting to collapse!
Perhaps the Star Tear was holding it all together.
Search team, this is the Captain! Get back here as fast as possible!

Fields.MenuText: I'm not sure I want this thing on my ship.
Do we have to take this thing?
This Star Tear better not turn the ship inside out or something like that.

Fields.DialogueText: Let me tell you, your U-Boot doesn't mind.
Do you have any other ideas? We can't let the Nixen get it, that's for sure.
There are no guarantees, Kapitän.
The boat is aboard, Kapitän.
Let's get out of here while we still can.
Kapitän! Ahead!
*ALARM*
Well, that's just great!
@BATTLE
I can only surmise that those final Nixen were somehow mutated by the Star Tear. It is possible that the energies of the Ritual somehow blasted back on her when we interrupted it.
And now we have it onboard. Super.
Ja, ja. But it seems to be inert.

Fields.MenuText: Yeah, and we have such a great track record with bringing seemingly benign occult objects aboard.
Try not to be too disappointed.
Yeah. I'm still glad we have it and the Morganas don't.

Fields.DialogueText: Sarkasmus was hardly called for.
Trust me. I'm not.
Ja. Agreed.
Do you think we should put it in a museum?
Machst du Witze? That's the last place it belongs. This thing is dangerous. I say... lock it in the biggest vault we can find.
That might not be such a bad idea.
But only after I get to study it.
Kapitän! We...
Yeah, yeah. Morganas approaching. Those ones are late to the party, though.
*ALARM*
Let's humour them, anyway.
@BATTLE
